description.narrative: The PRGT is the IMF’s main instrument for providing concessional financial support to low-income countries (LICs). The PRGT framework entails three concessional facilities: the Extended Credit Facility (ECF), which provides medium-term support to LICs with protracted balance of payments problems; the Standby Credit Facility (SCF), which provides financing to LICs with short-term balance of payments needs; and the Rapid Credit Facility (RCF), which provides rapid low-access financing with limited conditionality for countries facing urgent balance of payments needs. Currently, interest rates are zero for all three facilities. PRGT lending is supported by a model that relies on both loan and subsidy resources. Loan resources are provided through bilateral loan agreements with members. These loans are andsubsequently lent through to recipient countries via on-lent by the by the PRGT on a pass-through basis to LICs. Loan resources are mobilized periodically depending on expected resource needs. Via the Netherlands Central Bank (DNB) and the Ministry of Finance, the Netherlands recently granted an additional loan of SDR 500 million (EUR 602 million) Subsidy resources— which include balances in the PRGT’s subsidy accounts and Reserve Account as well as any investment earnings on these accounts—are used to cover the interest cost of PRGT loans, so that borrowers can benefit from concessional interest rates. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to an unprecedented surge in demand for concessional support from the IMF. In this light, new loan resources worth of SDR 14.57 billion(EUR 17,54 billion) have been mobilized by augmentations of existing agreements with existing lenders and a new one (Australia). To make these loans concessional to LICs, the PRGT’s subsidy gap is estimated at around SDR 2–3 billion (EUR 2,41-3,61 billion) under current policies between 2020-2024 if the self-sustained lending envelope is adjusted to cover LICs’ evolving financing needs.
